"CLARIFICATION OF PRIVATE RIGHT OF ACTION AGAINST TERRORIST STATES; DAMAGES." The text clarifies the right of action against foreign states designated as state sponsors of terrorism or their officials, employees, or agents, making them liable to US nationals. The text outlines the right of action against foreign states or their officials for personal injury or death caused by their acts, allowing US courts to maintain jurisdiction for money damages. The text allows US courts to hold foreign states or their officials liable for money damages in actions for personal injury or death caused by their acts, including punitive damages. Foreign states are vicariously liable for the actions of their officials, employees, or agents. The text allows US courts to hold foreign states or their officials liable for money damages in actions for personal injury or death caused by their acts, including punitive damages. An appeal in the courts of the United States in an action brought under paragraph (1) may be made only from a final decision under section 1291 of this title, and then only if filed within 30 days after the entry of such final decision. SEC. 2. PROPERTY SUBJECT TO ATTACHMENT EXECUTION. Section 1610 of title 28, United States Code is amended to allow for the execution of property interests of foreign states or their entities upon judgment under section 1605(a)(7), regardless of the level of control or profit distribution by the foreign government. The amendment to Section 1610 of title 28, United States Code allows for the execution of property interests of foreign states or their entities upon judgment under section 1605(a)(7), regardless of government control or profit distribution. This ensures that U.S. sovereign immunity does not apply to property interests regulated by the United States Government due to actions taken against a foreign state under certain acts. The amendments made by this Act apply to any claim for which a foreign state is not immune under section 1605(a)(7) of title 28, United States Code, arising before, on, or after the date of the enactment of this Act. In cases where an action was dismissed before the Act's enactment but would now be cognizable, the 10-year limitation period provided under section 1605(f) of title 28, United States Code, shall be tolled.
